awd_titl_txt: Casting Inorganic Nanostructure Arrays with 3D DNA Crystal Molds
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant is for research in the fabrication of arrays of inorganic nanostructures with prescribed three-dimensional shapes using DNA crystals with programmable three-dimensional cavities as "molds". The key innovation in this work is to develop a general platform to enable the use of micron-scale porous DNA crystals as templates to control both the shape and the architectural arrangements for inorganic materials. DNA crystals with prescribed three-dimensional cavities will be assembled in one-pot or one-reactor reactions. The cavities will serve as nano-molds, and the subsequent in-situ casting of metal structures within the mold cavities will produce metal particles of prescribed shapes, and importantly, these particles will be arranged with 3 nm precision over micron-scales.

The results of this research will provide a mass production methodology for metal nanostructure arrays with prescribed morphologies and with sub-10 nm fabrication resolution and 3 nm positioning precision. This will provide a generalizable platform for the nanofabrication of inorganic materials, and, in turn, enable diverse transformative applications in fields ranging from bio-sensing to energy storage and photonics. For example, the metal particle arrays could serve as an enabling platform for developing highly sensitive and multiplexed (multiple signals) biosensor arrays to detect biomedically relevant targets.  The precise control of electronic junction composition, orientation, and spacing of the metal structures could facilitate high photo-conversion efficiency in photovoltaics.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: PRESIDENT AND FELLOWS OF HARVARD COLLEGE

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit

1. We developed DNA brick epitaxy technique to raise the synthesis yield and decrease the defect rate of DNA brick crystals. According to classical epitaxy theory, we temporally separate the nucleation and stepwise growth processes of DNA brick crystals in a one-pot reaction system, thus to obtain micron-scale single domain crystals with prescribed channel/cavity arrays. This technique will enable scalable mass production of DNA brick crystals for high-resolution nano-manufacturing.

2. We developed the largest fully addressable and programmable self-assembly structure that has even been reported. Consequently, the casting cavity has been scaled up to 100 nm level at a voxel resolution of 2.8 nm * 2.8 nm * 4.4 nm inside the gigadalton-level DNA brick cuboid casting mold. This technique will enable integration of complex metallic nanostructures within single casting mold for superior plasmonic properties.

3. As complementary methodologies to nanocasting, we established high-precision DNA template directed assembly of 0D (Au NPs) and 1D (CNTs) as-synthesized nano-materials into 2D/3D architectures at lithographic precision. This study may provide a new patterning strategy that is compatible with and complementary to existing lithography and directed self-assembly strategies for scaling nano-electronics and opto-electronics.

Broader impact

Professional development

This NSF award has funded the professional development of no less than 10 postdoctoral fellows and graduate students.  The related projects have resulted in multiple presentations, poster sessions, and (pending) publications. Due to the interdisciplinary nature of DNA based nano-manufacturing, our team members have obtained systemic training in areas of synthetic biology, chemistry, nano-manufacturing, electronis and plasmonics. During the training we also developed novel methodologies adaptable to this interdisciplinary research topic. The leading researchers, Wei Sun and Jie Shen will continue to explore the foundations and strategies in their professional career.

Curriculum innovation.

We developed a new course inside Harvard medical school named Biologically Inspired Molecular Engineering, covering the design of programmable synthetic molecular systems and downstream applications. This course was initiated by Peng Yin (PI of NSF award 1333215) and William Shih in Spring 2011, and then opened to Harvard and MIT students annually from 2011 to 2016. We also expanded the tutorial scope annually based on our ongoing research. Beside the two leading PI, more than 10 postdoctoral fellows and graduate students from the PI’s lab are invited to present their research frontiers in the class every year.

Research for undergraduates.

Our labs have a track record of involving undergraduates in research, through summer research programs and as research assistants during the school year. Over the past 5 years, over 5 undergraduates have been mentored for the manufacturing related projects. For instance, one undergraduate, Casey Grun, helped our lab to develop DNA brick design software, which demonstrated reliable performance in gigadalton DNA brick project. 

 


Last Modified: 12/21/2017
Modified by: Peng Yin
